head.title: Ode IV. To Innocence.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 159-160. Raymond Havens lists “To Innocence” among the many poems influenced by Milton’s octosyllabic poems L’Allegro and Il Penseroso (1631). See Havens, The Influence of Milton on English Poetry, (New York: Russell & Russell, 1961, pp. 656 and 676).

l.emph: Useless are arms, for his defence,
That keeps a faithful guard of innocence.

body.bibl: Horace.22 Thomas Yalden, “Imitation of Horace, Book I. Ode XXII” in The Odes and Satires of Horace (London: John Baker, 1715), pp. 27-29.

lg.l: O Innocence, celestial maid,
In emblematic white array’d,
From thy empyrean height descend,
And all my wand’ring steps attend,
By thou my guardian, night and day,
And in temptation’s per’lous hour,
Thy heav’nly smile, and glorious ray,
Will dissipate the tyrant’s pow’r.
Then, let capricious fortune wear
A pleasing smile, or frown severe;
Let each malignant pow’r advance,
Let horror shake her dreadful lance,
Let meager poverty disclose,
A series of impending woes;
Yet, under thy auspicious sway,
All those shall not my soul dismay.
Let tongues malevolent proclaim,
And foul mouth’d slander blast my name,
Let envy rear her hideous form,
And ignorance ferment the storm;
Yet thou canst ev’ry care beguile,
Laugh at their frowns, nor court their smile;
Firm as a rock, on Albion’s shore,33 Derived from the Latin albus, meaning white, Albion is an ancient name for Britain referencing the island’s southern coast.
Canst hear the growling tempest roar.
Through life’s tempestuous busy scene,
’Tis thou canst make my way serene;
Devoid of guilt what can I fear,
Whilst thou, my guardian pow’r, art near:
Though death’s dark gates were open’d wide,
And all his gloomy cells display’d,
Be thou, O Innocence, my guide,
Than shall I enter undismay’d.
